```{r}
library(tidyverse)
```

```{r}
weather_df = 
  rnoaa::meteo_pull_monitors(
    c("USW00094728", "USW00022534", "USS0023B17S"),
    var = c("PRCP", "TMIN", "TMAX"), 
    date_min = "2021-01-01",
    date_max = "2023-12-31") |>
  mutate(
    name = recode(
      id, 
      USW00094728 = "CentralPark_NY", 
      USW00022534 = "Molokai_HI",
      USS0023B17S = "Waterhole_WA"),
    tmin = tmin / 10,
    tmax = tmax / 10) |>
  select(name, id, everything())
```

## Same plot from last time

Can add filters, mutate the data instead of editting the graph itself 

```{r}
weather_df |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = tmin, y = tmax, color=name)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = .5) +
  labs(
    title = "Temperature plot",
    x = "Min daily temp (Degrees C)",
    y = "Max daily temp",
    color = "Location",
    caption = "Max vs min daily temp in three locations; data from rnoaa"
  ) +
  scale_x_continuous(
    breaks = c(-15, 0, 15),
    labels = c("-15 C", "0", "15")
  ) +
  scale_y_continuous(
    position = "right",
    trans = "sqrt",
    limits = c(0, 30)
  )
```

what about colors...

continuous variables handled differently than categorical

scale_color_hue() works for continuous data 

viridis vs ggplot color palette (generally use viridis color palette)

```{r}
weather_df |> 
  ggplot(aes(x = tmin, y = tmax, color=name)) + 
  geom_point(alpha = .5) +
  labs(
    title = "Temperature plot",
    x = "Min daily temp (Degrees C)",
    y = "Max daily temp",
    color = "Location",
    caption = "Max vs min daily temp in three locations; data from rnoaa"
  ) + 
  viridis::scale_color_viridis(discrete = TRUE)
```
